title.narrative: Soutien à la Conférence canadienne sur la santé mondiale 2020
Support to Canadian Conference on Global Health 2020

description.narrative:
Le programme Santé des mères et des enfants du CRDI (ainsi que le précédent programme) ont soutenu financièrement la Conférence canadienne sur la santé mondiale (CCSM), dirigée par la Société canadienne de santé internationale depuis plus de dix ans. Depuis 2017, l’initiative Innovation pour la santé des mères et des enfants d’Afrique (ISMEA) contribue également à ce soutien. L’ISMEA est une initiative d’une durée de sept ans financée à hauteur de 36 millions de dollars par Affaires mondiales Canada, le CRDI et les Instituts de recherche en santé du Canada (IRSC).
Le thème de la CCSM 2020 est « La santé mondiale face au changement climatique », les thèmes transversaux étant l’équité et l’innovation. En réponse aux restrictions mises en place en raison de la pandémie de COVID-19, la conférence se tiendra virtuellement du 19 au 22 octobre 2020. Elle comprendra des séances plénières, des symposiums, des ateliers, des séances spéciales, des forums interactifs, ainsi que des présentations orales et par affiches. Cette année, on renoncera aux frais de participation pour tous les participants des pays à faibles revenus et à revenus intermédiaires.
La CCSM est la grande conférence sur la santé mondiale au Canada. Chaque année, elle offre aux Canadiens travaillant dans le domaine de la santé mondiale l’espace le plus important pour se rencontrer et échanger entre eux, ainsi qu’avec des collègues du monde entier.

The Maternal and Child Health program (and its predecessor) have financially supported the Canadian Conference for Global Health (CCGH) run by the Canadian Society for International Health (CSIH) for more than ten years. Since 2017 the Innovating for Maternal and Child Health in Africa (IMCHA) initiative has also contributed to that support.
The theme for 2020 is “Global health in a changing climate”. Cross cutting themes include equity and innovation. Responding to the restrictions due to the COVID 19 pandemic, the conference will be held virtually October 19-22, 2020. It will have plenary sessions and symposia as well as workshops, special sessions, interactive forums, and oral and poster sessions. Participation fees for all low- and middle-income countries (LMIC) participants will be waived this year.
CCGH is the major global health conference in Canada and is the primary space for Canadians working in global health to connect annually with each other and with colleagues around the world. CCGH engages health care practitioners, researchers, academics, educators, policy makers, and community advocates. Considering the delegates who attend, CCGH is an ideal location to showcase IMCHA’s work.
Supporting CCGH2020 will contribute to increased visibility of IMCHA, including through three confirmed dedicated concurrent sessions. The conference will also create a space to share other IMCHA products such as the legacy videos. Furthermore, IDRC is invited to speak at a plenary session.

title.narrative: Monitoring, evaluation, and learning support to the SERRC Initiative
Suivi, évaluation et soutien de l’apprentissage dans le cadre de l’initiative Réponse sociale et économique et reprise après la COVID-19

description.narrative:
En avril 2020, le CRDI a lancé un appel à propositions dans le cadre d’un mécanisme de financement à réponse rapide permettant à des organismes particuliers d’apporter des recherches, des constatations et des données pour des solutions politiques et pratiques afin d’atténuer les conséquences sociales et économiques de la pandémie de COVID-19 et de promouvoir la reprise dans les pays à faible revenu. À la suite de l’appel, une cohorte de 21 projets regroupant des think tanks ainsi que des organismes de recherche du Sud ont été approuvés aux fins d’un financement dans le cadre du mécanisme, qu’on appelle maintenant « l’initiative Réponse sociale et économique et reprise après la COVID-19 ».
Parallèlement à ces projets de recherche, le CRDI appuie une stratégie de suivi, d’évaluation et d’apprentissage (MEL) afin de permettre l’adoption d’une approche à l’échelle de la cohorte en matière d’apprentissage institutionnel, d’adaptation, de rapports complets et de résultats mesurables. Compte tenu de la propagation régionale considérable et de l’éventail des points d’entrée dans le cadre de l’initiative Réponse sociale et économique et reprise après la COVID-19, le rôle de soutien de MEL sera essentiel pour saisir les répercussions à l’échelle de la cohorte, tout en reconnaissant la diversité des contextes, des régions et des objectifs. Les activités comprendront le peaufinement d’une voie d’impact, l’élaboration d’outils de rapport technique, et la fourniture de rapports de synthèse des conclusions obtenues durant les périodes visées par le rapport technique.

In April 2020, IDRC launched a call for proposals under a rapid-response funding mechanism to specific organizations to contribute to research, evidence, and data for policy and practice solutions to mitigate the social and economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic and to promote recovery in low-income countries. Following the call, a cohort of 21 projects with think tanks and research organizations from the Global South were approved for funding under the mechanism, now referred to as the Social and Economic Response and Recovery from COVID (SERRC) Initiative.
Alongside those research projects, IDRC is supporting a monitoring, evaluation, and learning (MEL) strategy to allow for a cohort-wide approach to institutional learning, adaptation, comprehensive reporting, and measurable results. Given the considerable regional spread and range of entry points under the SERRC Initiative, the MEL support role will be critical in capturing cohort-level impacts while recognizing the diversity in contexts, regions, and objectives. Activities will include refining an impact pathway, developing technical reporting tools, and providing synthesis reports of findings from technical reporting periods.

title.narrative: The impacts of COVID-19 responses on the political economy of African food systems (COVID-19-AFS)
Évaluer les répercussions des réponses à la COVID-19 sur l’économie politique des systèmes alimentaires en Afrique (COVID-19 et SAA)

description.narrative:
IDRC’s response to the COVID-19 crisis includes a rapid response to the food and nutritional security crisis associated with COVID-19. This response mechanism supports the development of new, short-term activities that supplement existing projects. The goals are to document the impact of the pandemic (and control measures) on local food systems and food security; to document planned and spontaneous responses to the emerging crisis; and to strengthen responses to the current crisis. The rapid response mechanism also supports the development of new projects that document and analyze the efficacy of those responses. This will help low- and middle-income countries respond more efficiently to subsequent waves of the epidemic and to potential future shocks.
This project aims to implement action-oriented research on the impacts of COVID-19 interventions on the functioning and structure of food systems in Tanzania, Ghana, and South Africa. These three countries cover a spectrum of different economies, food systems, and COVID-19 responses. The research team will collect and analyze information across formal and informal food systems using a mixed-methods approach. By mapping food flows, key informant interviews, ethnographic field and online research, and collecting voice notes and video material, the project will gain a real-time understanding of the direct impacts of regulatory responses on production systems, value chains, and formal and informal markets by focusing on women and marginalized actors. The findings will be packaged and disseminated for policy, advocacy, and academic purposes.

La réponse du Centre de recherches pour le développement international à la crise de la COVID-19 comprend une réponse rapide à la crise de sécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle associée à cette pandémie. Ce mécanisme de réponse soutient la création de nouvelles activités à court terme qui complètent les projets existants. Les objectifs consistent à documenter les répercussions de la pandémie (et les mesures de contrôle) sur les systèmes alimentaires locaux et la sécurité alimentaire, à documenter les réponses planifiées et spontanées à la crise émergente, et à renforcer les réponses à la crise actuelle. Le mécanisme de réponse rapide soutient également l’élaboration de nouveaux projets qui documentent et analysent l’efficacité de ces réponses. Cela aidera les pays à revenu faible ou intermédiaire à répondre plus efficacement aux vagues ultérieures de l’épidémie et à d’éventuels chocs futurs.
Ce projet vise à mettre en œuvre une recherche orientée vers l’action et portant sur les effets qu’ont les interventions liées à la COVID-19 sur le fonctionnement et la structure des systèmes alimentaires en Tanzanie, au Ghana et en Afrique du Sud. Ces trois pays représentent un éventail d’économies, de systèmes alimentaires et de réponses à la COVID-19 différents. L’équipe de recherche recueillera et analysera des renseignements sur les systèmes alimentaires formels et informels en utilisant une approche mixte. En cartographiant les flux alimentaires, en interrogeant des informateurs clés, en effectuant des recherches ethnographiques sur le terrain et en ligne, et en recueillant des notes vocales et du matériel vidéo, le projet permettra de comprendre en temps réel les effets directs des réponses réglementaires sur les systèmes de production, les chaînes de valeur et les marchés formels et informels en se concentrant sur les femmes et les acteurs marginalisés. Les résultats seront formatés et diffusés à des fins d’établissement de politiques, de sensibilisation et pédagogiques.

title.narrative: Documenter la zone de planification spéciale et le processus de réaménagement du quartier informel de Mukuru à Nairobi
Documenting the special planning area and redevelopment process in Nairobi’s Mukuru informal settlement

description.narrative:
Les habitants du quartier informel de Mukuru, qui abrite environ 10 % de la population de Nairobi, ont dû faire face à de nombreux défis pour accéder aux services (eau, électricité, logement et éducation) et à des droits fonciers sûrs. Après des années de recherche à impact élevé et d’interactions fructueuses avec les autorités locales et nationales, l’administration du comté de Nairobi a déclaré l’établissement d’une zone de planification spéciale pour Mukuru en août 2017. La zone de planification spéciale a gelé le développement à Mukuru tandis qu’un consortium de quarante organisations locales a élaboré un plan d’aménagement intégré. Ces derniers mois, dans le cadre de leur réponse à la pandémie de COVID-19, les Services métropolitains de Nairobi ont commencé à mettre en œuvre ce plan et alloué 12 millions de dollars pour le développement des infrastructures pendant l’exercice en cours.
Ce projet soutiendra les efforts de l’Akiba Mashinani Trust pour documenter et diffuser les enseignements tirés d’un processus novateur et transformationnel visant à réaménager le quartier informel de Mukuru. Par le biais de recherches sur le terrain, de réunions de mobilisation stratégique, d’ateliers et d’événements de diffusion, le projet vise à saisir les premiers efforts de mise en œuvre du plan de réaménagement de la zone de planification spéciale. En documentant les leçons retenues et les pratiques exemplaires émergentes, ces efforts d’application des connaissances cherchent à saisir, d’une part, l’histoire complète de la zone de planification spéciale et à la raconter du point de vue des personnes qui en étaient les plus proches. La priorité sera accordée à la saisie des expériences uniques en leur genre de différents groupes, comme le leadership des femmes et des jeunes au fil des ans. D’autre part, des activités sont prévues pour communiquer des constatations à des publics mondiaux dans le but d’améliorer les approches en matière de planification et de gouvernance urbaines dans des contextes de pauvreté urbaine et d’informalité généralisées.

Residents of the Mukuru informal settlement, home to approximately 10% of Nairobi’s population, have faced many challenges in gaining access to services (water, electricity, housing, and schooling) and secure land tenure. After years of high-impact research and successful engagement with local and national authorities, the Nairobi County government declared a special planning area for Mukuru in August 2017. The special planning area froze development in Mukuru while a consortium of forty local organizations developed an integrated development plan. In recent months, as part of its response to the COVID-19 pandemic, Nairobi Metropolitan Services has started implementing the plan and allocated $12 million for infrastructure development during the current financial year.
This project will support the efforts of Akiba Mashinani Trust to document and disseminate lessons learned from an innovative and transformational process to redevelop the Mukuru informal settlement. Through field research, policy engagement meetings, workshops, and dissemination events, the project aims to capture first efforts to implement the special planning area redevelopment plan. In capturing lessons learned and emerging best practices, these knowledge translation efforts seek, on one level, to capture the full history of the special planning area story and tell it from the perspectives of the people who were closest to it. Priority will be placed on capturing unique experiences of different groups, like the leadership of women and youth populations over the years. On another level, activities are planned to share findings with global audiences, with the aim of improving urban planning and governance approaches in contexts of widespread urban poverty and informality.

title.narrative: Oplysningspuljen 2020

description.narrative:
1) Oplysningsprojekter 14,3 mio. kr. 2) Administrationsomkostninger 1,7 mio. kr. 3) Verdensbilledlegatet 1,3 mio. kr.
1) Tilskud til oplysningsprojekter, herunder også undervisningsmaterialer, til den brede danske befolkning om forhold i vækst- og udviklingslandene. 2-3 ansøgningsrunder pr. år. Alle projekter over 50.000 kr. vurderes af udvalget. Projekter under 50.000 kan vurderes på sekretariatsniveau.
2) Administration, drift og udvikling af Oplysningspuljen, herunder udgifter til det eksterne udvalg (honorar), udgifter relateret til udvalgsmøder, IT-udgifter inkl. licens til TAS.
3) Videokonkurrence blandt studerende om rejselegater til et vækst- eller udviklingsland. Verdensbilledlegatet blev ikke afholdt i 2020 pga COVID-19. Konkurrencen projetledes eksternt (Buchs A/S).
Rammen for formidlingen til den danske befolkning er verdensmålene. Det er en forudsætning for støtte, at rejsemålene og det land/de lande, som et oplysningsprojekt har fokus på, er i overensstemmelse med DAC-listen.

title.narrative: Denmark's contribution to WHO COVID-19 SPRP

description.narrative: The contribution is given towards the activities of WHO's Strategic Preparedness and Response Plan (SPRP) and it's ODA eligible activities. SPRP outlines the public health measures that the international community stands ready to provide to support all countries to prepare for and respond to COVID-19. Denmark's contribution will be used primarily for countries listed under Levels 1-3 of WHO’s SPRP Country Preparedness and Response Status for COVID-19 (version 9 April 2020), with the exemption of Cook Island.

title.narrative: Denmark's Contribution to WHO COVID-19 GHRP

description.narrative: The COVID-19 Global Humanitarian Response Plan (GHRP) is a comprehensive inter-agency response plan that aggregates and updates relevant existing humanitarian appeals from UN and non-UN entities, including WFP, WHO, IOM, UNDP, UN-Habitat, UNFPA, UNHCR, UNICEF and taking into consideration the International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement. The Plan focuses on preparedness and response to the initial immediate and urgent health and non-health needs and response to the pandemic, including to secure supply chains and humanitarian personnel mobility. The project will only cover WHO's activities under the GHRP.

title.narrative: CEPI core contribution 2020

description.narrative: Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations - CEPI - is not-for-profit and works to ensure a fair access to vaccines, surmountable prices and availability in areas that are most affected by new and emerging diseases – in particular low income countries. CEPI works in close partnership with WHO and the World Bank and has become one of the lead actors on vaccine development – both in regards to preparedness, but also to response and immediate needs such as the COVID-19 pandemic – and has the institutional expertise, networks, and agility to move rapidly.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Multi-Partner Trust Fund

description.narrative:
UN interagency funding mechanism to support low- and middle income countries to respond to the COVID-19 crisis and recover from the socio-economic shocks.
In the first call for proposals, the COVID-19 MPTF is open to 46 Least Developed Countries (LDCs), Lower Middle-Income Countries and selected Small Island Developing States (SIDS). These countries are not covered by the COVID-19 Global Humanitarian Response Plan. There will be addiitonal calls to follow.

title.narrative: Women Deliver - Bridging Grant 2020

description.narrative: The strategic objective is, by various means of advocacy, to reach and influence key decision-makers, and promote the uptake of data-driven recommendations on policies and investments related to gender equality in key international NGOs, UN Agencies and countries, with the aim to accelerate progress towards improving the health and rights of women and girl globally and in developing countries. The objective will be achieved through 1) communication and advocacy materials developed and disseminated in Kenya and globally that contribute to shifting the narrative to prioritize gender equality and girls and women’s health and rights, 2) Technical support on gender equality and girls’ and women’s health and rights, including SRHR and the COVID-19 response and recovery, provided to UN agencies and through Women Deliver participation on key task forces and initiatives, and 3) Support to networks of advocates, in order to push for progress on gender equality and girls’ and women’s health and rights, including in the COVID-19 response and recovery, globally and in Kenya.

title.narrative: Evaluating legal and policy responses to COVID-19 from a HR perspective in developing countries

description.narrative: The project is focused on the state of human rights during the COVID-19 pandemic. RWI will undertake a systematic analysis of human rights implications of COVID-19 response and recovery measures in 15 developing countries. The main outputs of the project will be: a refined tool that facilitates constructive engagement with states on the human rights implications of legal and policy measures adopted in response to COVID-19, 15 national law and policy reports addressing the human rights-implications of COVID-19 response in the selected developing countries, a comparative analysis of good practices and issues of concern, and a global webinar. The project will lay the foundation for a more ambitious global initiative, which will provide agenda-setting for the post-pandemic world, as well as capacity building for national researchers and other actors, and a wider analysis of policy responses to the pandemic worldwide.

title.narrative: Center for Global Development Partnership 2020-2023

description.narrative:
This partnership aims to provide real-time analysis, evidence-based solutions, and actionable recommendations to help policymakers and other stakeholders mitigate the impact of COVID-19 in LMICs and prepare for future global pandemics.
The partnership will focus on three cross-cutting and overarching objectives: a) Advancing a more resilient global health system and fit-for-purpose preparedness and response infrastructure for LMICs: b) Strengthening global health supply chains and promoting sustainable models for global health innovation and access to make markets work better for the poor in LMICs c) Advancing an effective and coordinated international response to economic challenges in LMICs

title.narrative: DMDP 2020 - SEGES, Indonesien

description.narrative:
Pilot Market Driven Organic Dairy Production in Indonesia (MDOD)
The project is a partnership between Arla, ICBP/Indolakto, SEGES/DAFC and Bina Swadaya. Partners have complementary capacity covering all aspects of the dairy value chain and responsible business conduct. The objective is to pilot a market driven and sustainable organic dairy production and to increase milk productivity as well as economic output of the dairy value chain in Indonesia. Interventions are designed to increase revenues at farm, dairy, sales and distribution levels, and to increase the number of decent jobs all along the dairy value chain, incl. on-farm jobs. Farmers converting to organic milk production, will be linked to a commercially viable and ‘green’ dairy value chain increasing their net income post COVID-19. The project is fully in line with governmental priorities of organic milk production. Focus is on farmers in East Java, but the model is scalable to other regions in Indonesia.

title.narrative: DMDP 2020 - BRAC, Bangladesh

description.narrative:
Safe water for all: a new partnership for growth in Bangladesh
This project’s development objective is to create inclusive and sustainable economic growth, increased income through improved and new jobs in water treatment and distribution (SDGs 1 and 8), and to increase access to safe and affordable drinking water for people in Bangladesh (SDG6) - supporting with economic recovery from Covid-19. The business objective is for Grundfos and Hydro to expand their businesses in the Bangladesh safe water market by creating a commercially viable business partnership model (SDG9) for cleaning industrial effluent (SDG12), reducing the harmful impacts of effluent on people and the environment (SDG3) and delivering safe drinking water (SDG6) whilst creating green jobs and additional income (SDG8) in the sector in process.

sector.narrative: Water supply and sanitation - large systems

title.narrative: Covid-19 III hjælpepakke - kapitalindskud til IFU til investering i African Guarantee Fund

description.narrative:
Mikro, små og mellemstore virksomheder (MSMV) udgør hjørnestenen i de afrikanske økonomier. Det er her, der sker lokal innovation, jobskabelse, grøn omstilling, etc. Men virksomhedernes vækstpotentialer er stærkt begrænset af utilstrækkelig adgang til lån til nød-vendige investeringer. Det vurderes, at omkring halvdelen af de estimerede 44 millioner formelle afrikanske MSMV’er mangler adgang til lånekapital for at kunne operere og vokse. Det skyldes, at bankerne anser risikoen for lån til virksomhederne for at være for høj. Co-vid-19 krisen har kun forværret denne udfordring. African Guarantee Fund (AGF) spiller en afgørende rolle ved at yde lånegarantier til afrikanske banker, så de kan investere og skabe jobs. AGF garanterer typisk 50% af bankernes lån til MSMV’erne. AGF har stor succes med at yde garantier til investeringer i grøn omstilling, som samtidig skaber mange nye jobs. AGF er i stand til at geare sin garantikapital med en faktor 8, dvs. at 1 kr. fra AGF’s garantikapital mobiliserer 8 kr. i privat kapital til MSMV investeringer. AGF har garantiaftaler med 160 banker og finansieringsinstitutioner i 40 afrikanske lande.
Tilsagnet på 60 mio. kr. ydes som et bidrag til IFU’s grundkapital øremærket formålet. Beløbet investeres i AGF. Tilsagnet på 60 millioner kr. er givet i forventning om, at IFU supplerer med 60 millioner kr. fra egne midler og samlet investerer 120 millioner kr. i B aktier i AGF. Kapitalbidraget skal styrke AGF’s grønne garantivirksomhed med henblik på at fremme jobskabelse gennem grønne SMV investeringer i Afrika.

title.narrative: Covid-19 III hjælpepakke - kapitalindskud til IFU til investering i African Guarantee Fund, engagement

title.narrative: Ghana: UNICEF Covid-19 response - IMPLEMENTATION

description.narrative: The overall medium-term objective of the project is to reduce the incidence of community transmission of COVID-19 (and by extension waterborne diseases) in poor urban settings, while increasing community resilience to disease outbreak and encouraging better health and hygiene seeking behaviour among vulnerable populations. Over the 12-month period of implementation, the project will deliver better WASH infrastructure and improved access to water, sanitation and hygiene in communities, including through health facilities and schools, to help address the preventive and curative needs of 6-8 low-income urban communities and benefitting approximately 50-80,000 people. The project will also promote hygiene and health seeking behaviour and increased access to welfare/ protection systems by women, adolescent girls and children, including in respect to SGBV. The project will also improve information systems for service delivery planning, and preparedness and response in urban settings.

title.narrative: Danish Support to ESMAP's Fighting COVID-19 with Sustainable Energy

description.narrative: The Danish Government approved the third COVID-19 emergency response package to developing countries 17 October1, 2020. In total, 13 Danish financed initiatives were endorsed by a broad political mandate and joined press release published. The package also included the present contribution to ESMAP’s COVID-19 response and amount of DKK 40.0 million. The Danish support to ESMAP’s proposal “Fighting COVID-19 and Strengthening Health Infrastructure with Sustainable Energy” will contribute to provide reliable energy to the health clinics in Sub-Saharan Africa while simultaneous demonstrate how renewable energy can replace traditional diesel generators. The Response programme aims to support at least ten low-income and fragile countries, provide 1,000 health clinics with renewable energy, improve conditions for more than 7 million patients, mobilise US$100 million IDA funding and support at least 75 energy companies to benefit from the Energy Access Relief Fund. In short, the project aims to build back better and greener by improving the health systems’ ability to fight COVID-19 and demonstrate a transition to power public institutions with green energy while at the same time support the nascent off-grid solar energy industry in Africa to get through the financial crisis.

title.narrative: Covid 19 - UNICEF - Additional storage space for protective equipment for developing countries

description.narrative:
Covid-19: Appropriation regarding "Hjælpepakke III"
Due to the COVID-19 situation, UNICEF has been faced with a challenge as regards lack of storage space for COVID-19 protective equipment for one year.
The Equipment (hazard suits, gloves, needles etc.) from, amongst other, China and India for use in Africa and Asia.
In concrete logistical terms, the need is for 5.-6.000 Square Meters which extends above the current capacty available to UNICEF. For this reason, UNICEF needs to acquire new storage space for this need. UNICEF has identified storage space which will cost around DKK 0,9 million a month - or roughly 11 mio. for a year.
The amount exceeds UNICEFs ordinary storage space budget, which is under extra pressure due to the extra costs relating to COVID-19 response. For this reason, UNICEF has requested that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs supply financing for extra storage space in these extraordinary situations.

title.narrative: DACAAR activities in Afghanistan 2021

description.narrative: The proposed project aims at improving livelihoods, health and life quality on a sustainable basis for returnees, protracted IDPs and their vulnerable host communities. By the completion of the project, beneficiaries would have improved livelihoods as measured by reduced time in collecting water and increased time spent on food production, income generation and girls’ and boys’ education, improved health as measured by a reduction in water borne diseases, and an overall improvement in the quality of life as perceived by the targeted men, women, boys and girls. The integrated nature and the diverse targeting strategy of the interventions will enable addressing of the needs and priorities of the communities from different angles; access to and use of safe drinking water coupled with open defecation free villages and improved hygiene behavior will reduce the incidence of diseases (including COVID19) which will in turn enable communities to invest increased time, energy and resources into learning new skills and engaging in various farm and off farm income generating activities offered by the intervention. The interventions planned will particularly target at risk individuals and households such as women-headed households, youth susceptible to embracing negative coping mechanisms, impoverished farmers and individuals with disability. Based on learning since outbreak of Covid-19 in March 2020the interventions for this extension period will also focus on helping communities to reduce the negative economic impact of COVID19 pandemic.

title.narrative: Den 7. kapitaludvidelse af Den Afrikanske Udviklingsbank

description.narrative:
AfDB bidrager til økonomisk og social fremgang i Afrika. Banken yder lån til projekter og til at understøtte politikudvikling, reformer og styrkelse af institutioner i afrikanske medlemslande. I oktober 2019 indgik AfDB’s medlemslande en aftale om den største kapitaludvidelse i bankens historie på ca. 445,8 mia. kr. i indbetalt kapital fra de 27 ikke-afrikanske og 54 afrikanske medlemslande. Danmark og de øvrige nordiske lande var stærkt medvirkende til, at aftalen om kapitaludvidelsen kom til at indeholde ambitiøse mål for bankens arbejde med klima, jobs til unge, ligestilling og skrøbelighed. Danmark vil med vores bidrag til kapitaludvidelsen videre arbejde for, at banken øger sine investeringer i jobskabelse til unge og i den grønne omstilling, herunder at skabe adgang til vand og vedvarende energi i Afrika.
Kapitaludvidelsen af AfDB vil bidrage til at implementere bankens fem strategiske prioritetsområder: 1) Elektrificere Afrika; 2) Brødføde Afrika; 3) Industrialisere Afrika; 4) Integrere Afrika; 5) Forbedre livskvaliteten for den afrikanske befolkning. Dertil har AfDB et særligt fokus på de tværgående prioriteter: klima, skrøbelighed, ligestilling, god regeringsførelse, og jobs til unge. Endelig vil kapitaludvidelsen hjælpe afrikanske lande med at håndtere de akutte konsekvenser af COVID-19-krisen og sikre en grøn og inklusiv genopbygning efter krisen.
AfDB er en væsentlig kilde til finansieringen af Verdensmålene og klimadagsordenen i Afrika. Særligt kan fremhæves mål 1 (Afskaf fattigdom), mål 8 (Anstændige jobs og økonomisk vækst), mål 10 (Mindre ulighed), og mål 13 (Klimaindsats).

title.narrative: Enhancing the Safety of Journalists in Africa and the Arab Region - UNESCO (media freedom, freedom of expression)

description.narrative: With its mandate in the field of communication and information, UNESCO leads the efforts of the UN System to secure freedom of expression, media freedom, safety of journalists, access to information and combatting mis- and disinformation. The Organisation has provided an important voice to these issues during the COVID-19 pandemic and will continue to counter its negative effects in the aftermath. Denmark is a member (2019-2023) of the Intergovernmental Council of UNESCO's International Programme for the Development of Communication (IPDC) and is heavily engaged in UNESCO's ongoing efforts on freedom of expression, the rights and safety of journalists, and combatting disinformation. The idea is to build on the political engagement by supporting these efforts in developing countries with a financial contribution to a UNESCO-project (2021-2022), enhancing the safety of journalists in Africa and the Arab region. The project will be closely linked to UNESCO's Multi Donor Special Account on Freedom of Expression and Safety of Journalists, which is primarily funded by other Nordic countries. The effort will help respond to pertinent issues on rights and freedoms arising from the COVID-19 crisis, where the global media landscape has faced challenges including legislative changes, policies, and other measures, altering the working conditions of media professionals, during and after the Pandemic. The objective is to contribute to peace, sustainable development, and democracy through promoting human rights and the safety of journalists, in support of the UN Plan of Action on the Safety of Journalists and the Issue of Impunity (UN Plan), by focusing on the UN Plan’s “Three Ps”: the prevention, protection against, and prosecution of crimes and attacks against journalists. The work of UNESCO in supporting free, pluralistic, independent, safe, and gender-sensitive media is relevant to several objectives of Denmark. title.narrative: Support to AmplifyChange 2021-23 - Strengthening Civil Society Advocacy for SRHR

description.narrative: A number of donors established the SRHR fund operating under the name AmplifyChange in 2014 The fund was established as a response to an identified challenge faced by small and medium sized civil society ( in developing countries to access funds from traditional donors recognizing the potential embedded in building the capacity of these small and medium si z ed CSO to advance the SRHR agenda. AmplifyChange is a well known advocate for improved policy and action on the most neglected SRHR issues F rom inception in 2014 AmplifyChange has over a 5 6 years period built its brand and an administrative set up capable of managing a large number of small and medium size projects, and developed an innovative virtual platform for knowledge sharing and tools for its grantees AmplifyChange uses a ‘call for proposals’ model in combination with activities for strengthening grantees’ organisational capacity. Since the start of the fund, about 750 grants hav e been approved to a varied range of groups, each working on a key aspect of SRHR. AmplifyChange showed its strength during the Covid 19 lock down where it quickly adapted to changing circumstances in the way of working and quickly set up webinars for its grantees and established a platform for grantees to share knowledge and ideas on how to continue working under Covid 19.

title.narrative: TMEA Regional (Grant from Denmark to the Safe Trade Emergency Facility Project) STEF Covid-19

description.narrative:
TMEA Regional (Grant from Denmark to the Safe Trade Emergency Facility Project) STEF Covid-19
The onset of COVID-19 crisis and its rapid transmission led to a flurry of Government Directives being issued by each country in the EAC to contain the pandemic's spread. One of the first areas of focus for reducing infections transmission was the transport and trade routes – considered to be significant infection conduits. The initial set of measures introduced to contain the spread of COVID-19 via air transport and along the trade routes lacked coordination between countries leading to several disruptions in regional and national supply chains. Directives and procedures were often conflicting, too high-level, and not sufficiently broken down into administrative Standard Operating Procedures for smooth application at the borders.

title.narrative: Denmark’s contribution to the United Nations Indigenous Fellowship Programme 2020-2021

description.narrative: The Indigenous Fellowship Programme (IFP) is a comprehensive human rights training programme that was established by the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) in the context of the first International Decade of the World's Indigenous Peoples (1995-2004). The programme aims to build the capacity and expertise of indigenous representatives on the UN human rights system and mechanisms dealing with human rights in general and indigenous issues in particular, so they are in a better position to protect and promote the rights of their communities. The IFP is held annually and fellows from the programme are trained together during 4 to 5 weeks in Geneva. The date of the training programme usually coincides with the annual meeting of the UN Expert Mechanism on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, thus allowing the fellows to participate more actively in international advocacy while participating in the Programme. In 2020, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the annual Fellowship Programme held in Geneva was cancelled and redesigned into a country-based programme with former Fellows posted as “Senior Fellows” in OHCHR country and regional offices, UN Country Teams (UNCTs) or UN Peacekeeping Operations.

title.narrative: Support to GAVI COVAX AMC facilitet 2021

description.narrative: The strategic objective of the GAVI COVAX AMC is: Providing effective, safe vaccines for those who need them most, regardless of wealth, on the same urgent timeline. Key result: At least 1.3 billion doses of COVID-19 vaccine have been provided among 92 low- and middle-income countries in 2021 through the Gavi COVAX Advance Market Commitment (AMC).

title.narrative: Support for UNICEF Supply Division COVID-19

description.narrative:
The contribution to UNICEF will be targeted two mutual-reinforcing aspects of the COVID-19 response and vaccine efforts:
1) UNICEF’s ACT-A Supply Financing Fund will be supported with DKK 30 million in order to; support the procurement of 50-100 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines, the procurement of 500 million syringes, 10,000 refrigerators, and freight and in-country delivery costs for receiving countries
2) Increased warehouse capacity in UNICEF Supply Division’s warehouse in Copenhagen in order to meet rising demands for effective storage and distribution of supplies in support of COVID-19 response and vaccination efforts. The additional storage space will allow for storage of pallets to store PPE, syringes and disposal boxes, oxygen concentrators and other key supplies.

title.narrative: Formulation Mission, including light touch review on existing program, The Danish Gulf of Guinea Maritime Security Program phase 3, 2022-2026 - Ghana

description.narrative: The purpose of the LTR is to assess the progress of the ongoing engagements under the Gulf of Guinea maritime security program ongoing phase II. The LTR will gather lessons learned including factors, which enhanced or hindered the implementation of project activities and gauge progress made towards the achievement of outcomes in the context of the Danish maritime security engagements in the Gulf of Guinea. The LTR will also assess good practices and the ability of implementing partners to deliver on project results and adapt to changes during project implementation. Finally, the LTR will provide recommendations, which in return will inform the formulation of the Maritime Security Program phase III, 2022-2026. The purpose of the Formulation is for the Consultant to conduct a formulation mission to the region, physical or virtual pending the development of the Covid-19 pandemic. The final product is the development of a Project Document (PD) detailing the broader Gulf of Guinea maritime security framework, including Peace and Stabilisation Engagement Documents (PSED’s) for each of the engagements under the Danish Gulf of Guinea Maritime Security Program phase III, 2022-2026. The PD, PSED’s and relevant annexes are to be quality assured by the MFA program committee and undergo a follow-up MFA technical appraisal. Finally, they will be approved by the Steering Committee for the Danish Peace and Stabilisation Fund in Q4 of 2021.

title.narrative: Credit and Financial Services: Joint Programme for the Sahel in Response to the Challenges of COVID-19, Conflict and Climate Change (SD3C-SEN)

description.narrative: The aim of the programme is to assist smallholders, particularly women and young smallholders living in border areas, to consolidate their livelihoods. The programme will help to diminish the constraints that exacerbate conflicts associated with anthropogenic impacts on natural resources and difficulties in gaining access to productive resources. The programme will also have an influence on the institutional capacity of the G5 Sahel in the area of inclusive social and political dialogue for peace and security by promoting the active engagement of producers¿ organizations and will also contribute to the development and promotion of the use of digital financial services with a view to making border transactions more secure.The aim of the programme is to assist smallholders, particularly women and young smallholders living in border areas, to consolidate their livelihoods. title.narrative: Irrigation: Project for Strengthening the Resilience of Small Farmers to the consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic

description.narrative: The project aims to increase the resilience capacity of smallholder farmers and vulnerable associative structures of rural communities through the rehabilitation of small productive irrigation infrastructures and the supply of agricultural inputs. Project goal. PURRACO project goal is to alleviate acute food insecurity and the drop in household incomes that result from COVID-19 containment measures. Specific objectives. Increase the resilience of smallholder farmers and rural organizations while supporting the rapid recovery of agricultural production and incomes through: (i) Rehabilitation of productive infrastructure (small-scale irrigation systems) and provision of agricultural inputs; and (ii) Support to short-cycle animal husbandry.The project aims to increase the support to the development of nutritious small livestock production models (goats, poultry and pigs) in order to mitigate the impacts of covid-19.

title.narrative: Objective Indicator 3

description.narrative: Levels of live coral coverage in dive sites and nondive sites

comment.narrative: Most Red Sea dive sites are being degraded by heavy and careless diving

No significant degradation measured in new dive sites to be opened to special seasonal tourists
Degradation in old dive sites does not increase

A monitoring workshop was prepared during which target species for each ecosystem were selected and an action plan was prepared to monitor them Two meetings were held to discuss these documents and introduce the prepared monitoring manuals for the selected target species The monitoring of most target species took place without followup this year monitoring of all target species will take place with aid from EPASP SEPA and NCS and the results of coral reef monitoring will be gathered

title.narrative: Annual Output Results
Output Indicator

description.narrative: At project end, achieved levels of revenue are within 10% of projection and the trend in growth rates sets the NCS on track to meet the optimal scenario.

comment.narrative: Financing of protected areas is below 20% of basic scenario.

At project end, achieved levels of revenue are within 10% of projection and the trend in growth rates sets the NCS on track to meet the optimal scenario by year 10. At least two new, reliable sources of funds are established. No significant degradation measured in new dive sites to be opened to special seasonal tourists. Degradation in old dive sites does not increase. Flagship species in PAs of terrestrial biomes recover or maintained, Comprehensive 5-year financing strategy, including a financial needs assessment defining targets, standards, procedures and criteria for resource allocation, is approved at ministerial level by end of year 2. Explicit policies and procedures to negotiate, monitor and implement institutional arrangements with business and social actors.Internal registry system (accounting system) for NCS established within EPF, accounting for revenues generated and disbursements, by end of project inception period. Revenue re-injection: A Ministerial Decree establishing a 10-year policy of achieving an optimal financing scenario largely through re-injected revenues.Financial sustainability unit established at Headquarters level.Revenues generated by PA system over 6-year project duration total approximately $74 milllion with final exact figures depending on final financial needs assessments and basic and optimal scenarios.Revenues re-injected into PA system over 6-year project duration total approximately $53 million, with final exact figures depending on final financial needs assessments and basic and optimal scenarios

Conducting the Willingness-to- Pay Survey to improve the fee collection system at five protected areas (Wadi Degla,Wadi El Rayan, Ras Mohamed , Wadi El Gemal and Blue Hole PAs ). The introduction of entrance fees at Wadi El Gemal NP The Development of Wadi Degla & Petrified Forest Sustainable Financing and Management Model .The Development of Blue Hole Diving site Sustainable Financing and Management plan. Review and update Wadi Degla Camping fees. Review and update PAs concession pricing system.The development of Conservation and sustainable management plan for Sharm El Sheikh marine environment and Ras Mohamed NP.The development of The Natural resources damage assessment study’. Conducting Baseline survey and sensitivity map and preparing site level management plan for Blue Hole Diving site .Supporting the procurement process to supply patrolling boats for Ras Mohamed NP, Wadi El Gemal NP and Northern Islands Marine Parks. The development of Conservation and sustainable management plan for Sharm El Sheikh marine environment and Ras Mohamed NP.The development of The Natural resources damage assessment study’ Conducting Baseline survey and sensitivity map and preparing site level management plan for Blue Hole Diving site Supporting the procurement process to supply patrolling boats for Ras Mohamed NP, Wadi El Gemal NP and Northern Islands Marine Parks.Developing the Zoning Plan for Ras Mohamed National Park and Wadi Degla. Conducting monitoring for natural resources focusing on four Flagship species at Wadi El Gemal NP.Development of Threatened Plants Management Plan in Saint Katherine PA. Conducting Technical Training on (Dealing with Sharks within Marine PA).• A long-term system-level financing strategy has been developed, approved and is currently under implementation • The development of "Institutional Reform Proposal" to upgrade NCS to an independent agency that has the suitable managerial structures to enable the national PAs systems to be more financially sustainable. • The new PAs Agency Proposal sent to Parliament, discussed and currently awaiting endorsement • The Project managed to allocate Governmental Cost sharing funds USD 1.8 M • The allocated revenues have been re-injected into the PAs system focusing on infrastructure and visitors' facilities development. • The Project managed to allocate Governmental Cost sharing funds USD 1.8 M • The allocated revenues have been re-injected into the PAs system focusing on infrastructure and visitors' facilities development.
• A new Financial Management System has been developed by the Project to facilitate Governmental spending and revenue re-injection policy • According to this new system the revenues are transferred from Ministry of Environment to a special PAs account at an independent third party Operationa Unite for Development Assistance (OUDA) of Ministry of International Cooperation • This new policy has proven to be very successful and efficient where the spending rate surpasses 95% last year
• Target achieved: A financial sustainability and economics unit was established within the NCS • The project is working closely with this unit and other department at Ministry of Environment to increase human capacities related to financial sustainability issues • Three pilot projects focusing on financial sustainability are currently been implemented at Wadi Degla, Petrified Forest and Blue Hole PAs A set of actions has been taken to develop enabling legal and regulatory framework for NCS financial sustainability. • This includes development of : The PA financing strategy, Institutional framework for the financial strategy resource mobilization strategy, economic valuation studies, concession management framework and the establishment of an independent agency for PAs (The Nature Conservation Authority). • The total revenues generated by PAs system in 2012-2017 is approximately $26 million. • During this reporting period: o USD 4.5 M has been allocated from Ministry of Environment to PAs system and injected into the PAs Special Account o Around USD 75000 of revenues has been generated from the newly introduced visitors entrance fees at Wadi El Gemal NP during the past six months • During this reporting period: o USD 1.8 M has been re-injected and spent for the PAs infrastructure and visitors’ facilities o Additional amount of USD 4.5 M has been re-injected and workplan has been prepared for the activities

Support local communities in South Sinai by completing El Gharana village and relocation of the local communities for better living conditions. support eco-tourism in South Sinai in the Blue Hole by upgrading the protected area and providing basic services to the visitors. Complete and implement he permit system into the protected areas. Apply the E-ticketing.

Due to unforeseen circumstances the project did not complete the El Gharana village relocation of the local communities however, the financial strategy of protected areas was completed and E-ticketing was applied thus increasing income to the protected areas which in turn will help in the upgrading of the areas. Upgrading of the Blue Hole completed with basic services making it a world class eco-touristic site. Permit system applied thus contributing to the nature conversation.

The introduction of entrance fees at Wadi El Gemal NP was applied The Development of Wadi Degla & Petrified Forest Sustainable Financing and Management Model completed The Development of Blue Hole Dive Site Sustainable Financing and Management plan completed with the necessary infrastructure to support the system. Review and update of Wadi Degla camping fees and of PA concession pricing system was applied. This resulted in income generation for the protected areas.

capital of a political entity

title.narrative: Activity web page
Annual Output Results
Output Indicator

description.narrative: New machinery installed (or old machines retrofitted) in the four target enterprises 2 Use of HCFC-141b discontinued in enterprises and replaced by methyl formate or n-pentane 3 Necessary old machine parts destroyed to prevent return to HCFC use 4 National imports of HCFCs monitored to double check phase-out has happened

comment.narrative: The four target enterprises’ HCFC-141b use remains at their current level, with old technology in place.

Phase-out of HCFC-141b at Cairo Foam 9.90 ODPT Phasing-out 9.90 HCFC-141 ODP (90 MT) and shift to a new ozone friendly technology Phase-out of HCFC-141b at MOG 13.90 ODPT phasing-out 13.90 HCFC-141 ODP (126 MT) and shift to a new ozone friendly technology Phase-out of HCFC-141b at Fresh 2.4 ODPT phasing-out 2.4 HCFC-141 ODP (22 MT) and shift to a new ozone friendly technology Phase-out of HCFC-141b at SECC 11.2 ODPT Phasing-out 11.2 HCFC-141 ODP (102 MT) and shift to a new ozone friendly technology Phase-out of HCFC-141b at Reftruck 11.66 ODPT phasing-out 11.66 HCFC-141 ODP (106 MT) and shift to a new ozone friendly technology Phase-out of HCFC-141b at ElFateh 11.83 ODPT phasing-out 11.83 HCFC-141 ODP (107.5 MT) and shift to a new ozone friendly technology Phase-out of HCFC-141b at DOW 4.44 ODPT Phasing-out 4.44 HCFC-141 ODP (40.4 MT) and shift to a new ozone friendly technology Phase-out of HCFC-141b at Technocom 13.09 ODPT Phasing-out 13.09 HCFC-141 ODP (119 MT) and shift to a new ozone friendly technology

Completion of the implementation from the signed memorandum of Agreement from DOW and EEAA and UNDP, for converting DOW’s system house from the use of HCFC-141b- to non-ODS-based technologies in the manufacture of fully formulated PU systems; and to permanently discontinue the use of HCFCs for 13 customers and we have been succeeded in phasing-out 4.44 HCFC-141 ODP (40.4 MT) and shift to a new ozone friendly technology. Completion of the implementation from the signed memorandum of Agreement from Technocom and EEAA and UNDP, for converting Technocom’s system house from the use of HCFC-141b- to non-ODS-based technologies in the manufacture of fully formulated PU systems; and to permanently discontinue the use of HCFCs for 11 customers and we have been succeeded in phasing-out 13.09 HCFC-141 ODP (119 MT) and shift to a new ozone friendly technology. The executive Committee of the multilateral fund for the implementation of the Montreal protocol approved in the eighty second meeting the third tranche of stage-I of the HPMP for the period 2018 to 2019, at a total funding US$716,400 for UNDP.

Reflect additional funding approved as part of the HCFC Phase out Management Plan (HPMP) Stage I for Egypt at the 82nd Meeting of the Executive Committee of the MLF for the Implementation of the Montreal Protocol held in Dec 2018.

Completion of the implementation from the signed memorandum of Agreement from Technocom and EEAA and UNDP, for converting Technocom’s system house from the use of HCFC-141b- to non-ODS-based technologies in the manufacture of fully formulated PU systems; and to permanently discontinue the use of HCFCs for 26 customers and we have been succeeded in phasing-out 26.84 HCFC-141 ODP (244 MT) and shift to a new ozone friendly technology.
Completion of the implementation from the signed memorandum of Agreement from Baalbaaki and EEAA and UNDP, for permanently discontinue the use of HCFCs for 14 customers and we have been succeeded in phasing-out 12.84 HCFC-141 ODP (116.7 MT) and shift to a new ozone friendly technology.
40 small and Medium co. phasing out 322 ton of 141b
The project has successfully phased out 322 tonnes of 141b reaching the target of complete phase out in phase I through the system house companies.

description.narrative: Quality of transport policies and level of inter-agency coordination -Level of public transport services and use of Intelligent Transport Systems -Level of road safety and eco-friendly transport

comment.narrative: -Lack of national transport strategy to guide sector activities as focus for inter-agency coordination -No public transport in cities, and ITS capacities not developed -High levels of road death rates and high levels of vehicle pollution levels
Strategic Planning Evaluation Activities conducted and defining Road Works and Project Alternatives.

The Project strives to advise the MOT with different strategic plans in transport sector includes but not limited to the following: 1. Climate Change Plans in Transport, the project involved MOT for the first time in climate change plans. 2. Integrated Coordination for Urban Transport Management. 3. Integrated policy for investment in roads, including privatization of some roads and applying tolls for road use. 4. Improving Aseer Roads Strategy. 5. Arterial Roads Strategy. All above Strategic Project advices leaded the MOT to sign an agreement between MOT and MOMR dated April 7, 2019 to make sure these advises described below may be implemented.
Minimize the rate of transportation accidents

The UNDP’s project with the Ministry of Transport aims at enhancing life in Saudi cities by reducing the rate of traffic accidents as well as increasing the use of public transportation. It also focuses on improving the transportation infrastructure including roads and highways along with their maintenance. The Ministry of Transport as policy leading agency for the transport sector is responsible for reporting and periodical review of the National Transportation Strategy (NTS). Within this national strategy, the project is aiming at developing sustainable transport systems and improving road safety. In the first three quarter of 2018 road fatalities have been reduced by around 18%. The project led to the development of Intelligent Transport System (ITS), and is currently in operation, which in turn reduces traffic accidents by alerting drivers of what is up ahead. In another aspect of the project, a system was established to monitor road maintenance contractor’s work which in turn enhances work quality.
Road Network Developed

• Identified an International Firm via Biding Process to work on the studies for Transit Roads outside the major cities in the Kingdom . Due to COVID-19 the studies have been delayed for the year 2021. • Providing continuous support to the development of Transport Data, Statistics and Analysis unit and system at MOT.
Transit Road outside Cities study completed

description.narrative: National Strategy Submitted to SEEC Board

comment.narrative: The Center is established and the Energy Efficiency Laws is drafted
Tp contribute reducing energy intensity in the country

As part of Energy Ecosystem in the Kingdom, SEEC has contributed with other entities and initiatives to reduce energy intensity in the country by 10% between 2012 and 2019. Listed are the major achievement in EE for the targeted sectors: • Industrial Sector: - Steel sub sector: 1.7% improvement in energy intensity levels - Cement sub sector: 2.0% improvement in energy intensity levels - Petrochemicals sub sector: 2.8% improvement in energy intensity levels
• Building Sector: Reduced the energy consumption of (the) government buildings by 14.45% in 2019 compared to 2018 despite the increase in buildings numbers.
• Transportation Sector: - New fleet efficiency improved by around 16% over the past 4 years. - Increased the number of efficient vehicles by 26% during (2016-2019). - Increased the number of efficient models of tires by 33%
Enhance Policies and Strategy for sustainable use of natural resources and environment and ensure enforcement of standards

In the Industrial sector, 60 targeted factories were visited, including the sectors of iron products, chemical, ceramic, paper and glass, in order to verify their received data and review the reports of each factory in preparation for setting a working mechanism to find opportunities to raise energy efficiency in them. In the Transportation sector, the database of used vehicles was updated to include the 2019 models, as well as the fuel economy standard specification to include electric cars, in addition to updating the fuel economy “Saudi CAFE” card specification, and the implementation of the second phase of the fuel economy card, which includes an additional level, "Excellent +" In the Buildings sector, the detailed design phase of the energy consumption intensity program in buildings has started, with the building of the government buildings consumption database and work on its operation. In addition, many initiatives were prepared, and initiatives were achieved to increase energy consumption efficiency in these sectors as follows: • Developed and approved the specification of minimum Energy Performance for the part three of the lighting products (street lighting) SASO 2927/2019 in July 2019. • Implemented the new energy efficiency labels, which adopted bars indicators instead of stars, for the household appliances. • Monitoring the enforcement of the all existing energy efficiency standards. • Launched an initiative to study the feasibility of transferring from Energy Efficiency Ratio (EER) to the Seasonal Energy Efficiency Ratio (SEER) to update the EE AC standards.
To increase energy efficiency awareness and introduce energy efficient technologies available on local market. Conduct Awareness campaigns for more than 250 schools and 70,000 student.

This UNDP project with the Saudi Energy Efficiency Center (SEEC) is to achieve the Kingdom’s goals for energy conservation and is the second phase of a capacity development programme for SEEC. With this goal in mind, a total of 10 national awareness campaigns were launched targeting different areas ranging from transportation to home appliance. One of the most prominent campaigns is “Letabqa” aimed at increasing energy conservation awareness. This campaign is an ongoing campaign with more than 425 million ad views on various internet platforms and applications. Energy efficiency labels were also added to some household electrical appliances expressing the energy efficiency of each individual appliance to make it easier for the consumer to make energy efficient choices. The project also included three interactive exhibitions for women around the Kingdom. Furthermore, 18 awareness programs were conducted for male and female students in schools and colleges throughout the Kingdom. By creating public awareness, this will help Saudi Arabia reach its goal in energy conservation of decreasing energy consumption by 20 percent by year 2030 in specific sectors. The project is due for final evaluation and development of a new phase with the Ministry (Project Document). https://ipeec.org/upload/publication_related_language/pdf/816.pdf
